summary: This is an FBI operations order form detailing the planned arrest of Jeffrey Epstein at Teterboro Airport on July 6, 2019, and the subsequent search of his New York City residence. It includes subject information, site surveys, team assignments, and the FBI deadly force policy.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the operations order; a registered sex offender scheduled to be arrested upon his return to the US. The document notes his criminal record and that he was observed carrying a handgun.

events.title: Planned Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Epstein, who was out of the country, was scheduled to return to the US via Teterboro Airport at 5:20 PM. Upon his return, Customs and Border Protection (CBP) would detain him, after which FBI agents and NYPD detectives would effect his arrest. Following the arrest, a search warrant for his New York premises would be executed.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to one count of solicitation of prostitution and one count of solicitation of prostitution with a minor in Florida.

locations: Teterboro Airport (111 Industrial Ave, Teterboro, NJ 07068)
9 East 71st Street, New York, New York (described as a nearly 19,000 square foot multi-story single-family residence)
New York Presbyterian/Cornell Medical Center (525 East 68th Street at York Avenue, Manhattan)
University Hospital, New Jersey (150 Bergen Street, Newark, New Jersey)
19th Police Precinct (153 East 67th Street, New York, NY)
keyFacts: The FBI had a detailed operations order for the arrest of Jeffrey Epstein on July 6, 2019, upon his scheduled return to the US via Teterboro Airport.
A confidential source (CHS) had observed Epstein carrying a 9mm handgun, which was noted as a reason for caution.
Following Epstein's arrest, a search warrant was to be executed at his nearly 19,000 square foot residence at 9 East 71st Street in New York City.
The operation involved coordination between the FBI, NYPD, and Customs and Border Protection (CBP).
The document includes the FBI's deadly force policy, indicating preparations for a potentially high-risk arrest.
